description: a(n) is the minimal prime q such that n(q+1)-1 is prime, that is, the smallest prime q so that n = (p+1)/(q+1) with p prime; or a(n) = -1 if no such q exists.
comments: A conjecture of Schinzel, if true, would imply that such a q always exists.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Matthew M. Conroy, A sequence related to a conjecture of Schinzel, J. Integ. Seqs. Vol. 4 (2001), #01.1.7.
Peter Luschny, Schinzel-Sierpinski conjecture and Calkin-Wilf tree.
example: 1 = (2+1)/(2+1), so the first term is 2; 3(2+1)-1=8 which is not prime, yet 3(3+1)-1=11 is prime (3 = (11+1)/(3+1)) so the 3rd term is 3.
maple: a:= proc(n) local q;       q:= 2;       while not isprime(n*(q+1)-1) do          q:= nextprime(q);       od; q    end:seq(a(n), n=1..300); # _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 11 2011
